title: 108_s2753
content: The Act titled "Zero Downpayment Act of 2004" provides insurance for zero-downpayment mortgages. The Zero Downpayment Act of 2004 amends the National Housing Act to allow the Secretary to insure zero-downpayment mortgages for single-family properties occupied by the mortgagor as their principal residence. The Zero Downpayment Act of 2004 allows the Secretary to insure zero-downpayment mortgages for single-family properties occupied by the mortgagor as their principal residence, including 1-family dwelling units in multifamily projects, cooperative housing corporation units, and manufactured homes with developed lots. Eligibility for insurance is subject to a maximum principal obligation limit. To qualify for insurance under this subsection, a mortgage must not exceed 100% of the property's appraised value, including certain fees. The mortgage insured here is not bound by other loan-to-value requirements. The mortgagor must be a first-time homebuyer. The mortgagor must be a first-time homebuyer and receive counseling approved by the Secretary on homeownership responsibilities and financial management. The mortgagor must receive counseling on homeownership options, financial implications, and other relevant information as required by the Secretary. The mortgagor must receive counseling on homeownership options, financial implications, and other relevant information as required by the Secretary, including details on the property appreciation needed for the mortgagor to recover the principal amount, costs financed under the mortgage, and estimated selling costs on specific anniversaries of the mortgage for 2- to 4-family residences. Residence counseling for landlords and tenants must include information on rights and obligations. Mortgagees can offer optional notice of foreclosure prevention counseling availability to eligible mortgagors. The Secretary approved providing notice and counseling to delinquent mortgagors. The notice must be given promptly after 60 days of delinquency, state the delinquency, provide contact information, and be given once per delinquency period. The housing counseling entity must notify a mortgagor promptly if they are 60 days delinquent on mortgage payments, offering foreclosure prevention counseling and providing contact information for assistance. Failure to provide the required written agreement can be corrected by sending it to the mortgagor as soon as possible after the delinquency occurs. The Secretary may establish penalties for mortgagees failing to provide required written agreements. Mortgagees are not liable for housing counseling entities failing to notify mortgagors. No private right of action is allowed under this section. No private right of action is allowed for the mortgagor under this section. The delinquency period for a mortgage begins when the mortgagor becomes delinquent and ends when payments become current or the property is foreclosed. Mortgages insured under this subsection are not subject to downpayment requirements. The Secretary shall review program performance for mortgages insured under this subsection and make necessary adjustments to ensure the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund generates a negative credit subsidy. Adjustments may include altering mortgage insurance premiums, reviewing underwriting policies, and limiting availability of mortgage insurance. To be eligible for insurance under this subsection, a mortgage must meet underwriting criteria using approved credit scoring systems and be made to mortgagees meeting established standards. To be eligible for insurance under this subsection, the mortgagee must provide the mortgagor with a written disclosure of the effective cost of borrowing the excess amount compared to a mortgage insured under subsection (b). The cost should be expressed as an annual interest rate over the first 5 years of the mortgage. Loss mitigation procedures are also outlined in case of default. Upon default of an insured mortgage, the mortgagee must engage in loss mitigation actions to prevent foreclosure. The Secretary must report to Congress annually on default and foreclosure rates for insured mortgages compared to other types of mortgages. The Secretary may establish additional requirements for mortgage insurance under this subsection. The aggregate number of insured mortgages in any fiscal year cannot exceed 30 percent of the total insured by the Secretary in the previous fiscal year. The authority to insure mortgages may be suspended under certain conditions. The authority to insure mortgages may be suspended if the claim rate exceeds 3.5 percent, and will remain in effect until the claim rate is 3.5 percent or less. The claim rate is the ratio of claims on insured mortgages to the number of mortgages with insurance in-force. The Secretary can endorse or insure mortgages executed before the suspension date. No new mortgages can be insured after September 30, 2011, except for those executed before that date. The Comptroller General must report on the performance of insured mortgages, and the Secretary can implement this subsection with interim rules, soliciting public comments. The Secretary can implement subsection with interim rules, soliciting public comments before issuing final rules. Amendment made to mortgage insurance premiums under the National Housing Act.
